headline.main: What We Eat: Doubts by the Teaspoonful

docs.abstract: Americans consume $1.5 billion in artificial sweeteners every year, but their use is often accompanied by lingering health concerns; decades of research has been inconclusive about sweetener safety, and consumer choices continue to be guided by whimsy rather than scientific fact (Series: What We Eat). Photo, Drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: White. Pink. Blue. Yellow. On restaurant tables everywhere, the colors of the sweetener packets instantly identify the contents.
docs.snippet: White. Pink. Blue. Yellow.     On restaurant tables everywhere, the colors of the sweetener packets instantly identify the contents.

headline.print_headline: What We Eat: Doubts by the Teaspoonful

docs.abstract: Despite decades of use and tests, many people have lingering concerns about the safety of the options available - mainly saccharin, aspartame and sucralose - with choices often based on hearsay, mythology and whim.
docs.snippet: Despite decades of use and tests, many people have lingering concerns about the safety of the options available - mainly saccharin, aspartame and sucralose - with choices often based on hearsay, mythology and whim.

headline.main: Comic Web Series Comes With a Quit-Smoking Sponsor

docs.abstract: Legacy, a nonprofit organization that has long sought to discourage younger Americans from smoking, is hoping a Web series on My Damn Channel will reach a younger audience of smokers.
docs.snippet: Legacy, a nonprofit organization that has long sought to discourage younger Americans from smoking, is hoping a Web series on My Damn Channel will reach a younger audience of smokers.
